dt.t: It's a conundrum for any playwright: How do you enliven characters who alternately bore and {wi}exasperate{/wi} each other?
It's a demanding dining experience that may exhaust and {wi}exasperate{/wi} some customers …

pt: {sc}irritate{/sc} {sc}exasperate{/sc} {sc}nettle{/sc} {sc}provoke{/sc} {sc}rile{/sc} {sc}peeve{/sc} mean to excite a feeling of anger or annoyance. {sc}irritate{/sc} implies an often gradual arousing of angry feelings that may range from mere impatience to rage.
{sc}exasperate{/sc} suggests galling annoyance and the arousing of extreme impatience.

pt.t: his {it}exasperating{/it} habit of putting off needed decisions

pt: {sc}nettle{/sc} suggests a sharp but passing annoyance or stinging.
{sc}provoke{/sc} implies an arousing of strong annoyance that may excite to action.
{sc}rile{/sc} implies inducing an angry or resentful agitation.

pt.t: the new work schedules {it}riled{/it} the employees

pt: {sc}peeve{/sc} suggests arousing fretful often petty or querulous irritation.

pt.t: a toddler {it}peeved{/it} at being refused a cookie
